abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Energy Efficiency
            Project for Poland were as follows: outcomes were moderately
            unsatisfactory: risk to global environment outcome was
            moderate; bank performance was moderately unsatisfactory;
            and borrower performance was moderately satisfactory. Some
            lessons learned includes; (i) innovative instruments should
            be kept simple with low transaction costs; (ii) Energy
            Service Company (ESCOs) need financial safety net in
            start-up phase; (iii) strong project pipeline is essential;
            (iv) active government and state institution role needed for
            an enabling ESCO environment; and (v) guarantee instruments
            often not critical for Energy Efficiency (EE) lending to happen.

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Energy Efficiency
            Project for Poland is to increase public and private sector
            investments in energy efficiency in buildings. The project
            has disbursed US$10.4 million out of the US$11 million
            Global Environmental Facility (GEF) grant and is well
            underway to reach its objectives. The reallocation is
            necessary to: (i) reallocate US$200,000 intended for the
            National Registry activity from the Technical Assistance
            (TA) category of expenditure to the goods category since the
            main part of the activity will be purchase of software, and
            (ii) reallocate remaining unused funds to the
            Thermo-Modernization (TM) Investment Component in order to
            fund additional TM investments.

display_title.display_title:
Poland - Energy Efficiency
            Project : restructuring : Main report

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Energy Efficiency
            Project for Poland is to increase public and private sector
            investments in energy efficiency in buildings. The project
            is only three and a half months from its closing date and
            that the ratification of the restructuring by Poland will
            take about three months; a twelve-month extension of the
            project closing date to June 30, 2012 is requested. This
            extension will ensure that the funds reallocated from the
            partial credit guarantee facility component to the new
            Thermo-Modernization (TM) investments component can be fully
            disbursed and that the studies under the Technical
            Assistance (TA) component can be completed in time. The
            requirements for an extension of the closing date are being
            met: 1) the project objectives continue to be achievable, 2)
            the performance of the recipient and Bank Gospodarstwa
            Krajowego (BGK) continue to be satisfactory, 3) BGK has
            prepared an action plan acceptable to the bank to complete
            the project in time, and 4) there are no outstanding audit
            reports for the project. The restructuring will take into
            account existing institutional and market capacities and
            will improve progress in meeting the project development
            objective. Uncommitted funds under the partial credit
            guarantee will be reallocated to a new support modality for
            Energy Efficient (EE) investments.

display_title.display_title:
Poland - Energy Efficiency
            Project : restructuring (Vol. 2) : Data sheet
